title: Judge bans warning signs outside sex offenders' houses to keep trick-or-treaters away
text:
A federal judge ruled that Butts County Sheriff Gary Long cannot put signs warning trick-or-treaters in three sex offenders’ yards. (Picture: Butts County Sheriff’s Office)

A judge has banned police from putting warning signs outside sex offenders’ houses in a bid to keep young trick-or-treaters away.

The federal judge ruled in favor of three sex offenders who sued Butts County Sheriff Gary Long, who put the signs in their yards last year and planned to do it again this year.

Sheriff Long’s signs feature stop signs and big bold capital lettering that reads: ‘WARNING! NO TRICK-OR-TREAT AT THIS ADDRESS’

Georgia state law prohibits registered sex offenders from putting Halloween decorations on their property – but they said the signs go too far.

Mark Yurachek, the lawyer representing the plaintiffs, Christopher Reed, Reginald Holden and Corey McClendon said: ‘State Law does require him to notify the public in very specific ways, and none of those ways includes placing signs on registrants’ lawns.’

Sheriff Long said: ‘My office took precautions and placed signs indicating ‘No Trick-or-Treat’ at each registered sex offender’s residence in the county. This was done to ensure the safety of our children.’

The sex offenders argued in the lawsuit that Sheriff Long ‘exceeded his authority’ when he put the signs up, according to the lawsuit. They also said he trespassed on their property when doing so.

The lawsuit continues to say that the police caused ‘anxiety, embarrassment and humiliation,’ and damaged their trust in law enforcement.

Judge Marc Treadwell ultimately ruled that the signs infringed on the three plaintiff’s rights to free speech – but the ruling did not extend to all sex offenders in the county.

However, the judge did ward Sheriff Long that he ‘should be aware that the authority for blanket sign posting is dubious at best and even more dubious if posted under the objection of restraints.’

After the ruling, Sheriff Long said he ‘respectfully and strongly’ disagreed with the judge and vowed to keep a ‘very strong presence in the neighborhoods where we know sex offenders are likely to be.’

A local mother, who remained unnamed, told Fox 8: ‘I understand that not all sex offenders are the same, but as an overall consensus I believe that we need (the signs).’

In every US state, a person may be ordered to register as a sex offender if they are arrested for public urination and are charged with indecent exposure or lewdness, according to Attorney Janet Portman.
